questions.text: Classify the fracture shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray shows a fracture of the neck of the humerus.

  • These fractures are classified according to Neer's classification based on the number of displaced fracture fragments.
  • Here, there are 2 fracture fragments - the shaft and head of the humerus. Hence, it is a 2-part fracture or Neer type II.

(Other options are ruled out)

questions.text: The 3-point bony relationship is altered in
questions.solution:
Jupiter fracture is another name for the intercondylar fractures of the humerus. These fractures will alter the 3 point bony relationship of the elbow.

  • The 3-point relationship defines the clinical relationship between the Medial epicondyle, the Lateral epicondyle and the Tip of the olecranon.
  • In a flexed elbow, the 3 points form an isosceles triangle, which is congruent with the opposite side.
  • In extended elbow - All 3 points form a straight line.

Explanation of Other Options

Supracondylar fracture of humerus (Option A): This does not alter the 3-point bony relationship. The olecranon, medial epicondyle, and lateral epicondyle alignment remains intact, helping to differentiate it from elbow dislocations or intercondylar fractures.

Monteggia fracture (Option C): In this injury, there is a fracture of the proximal ulna with dislocation of the radial head. The 3-point bony relationship around the elbow joint remains unaltered as the fracture-dislocation is of the forearm, not the distal humerus.

Radial head fracture (Option D): A radial head fracture affects the lateral elbow and does not disturb the alignment of the olecranon and epicondyles; hence, the 3-point bony relationship is preserved.

choices.text: French osteotomy is used for correction

questions.text: False about cubitus varus deformity in supracondylar fracture is.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cubitus varus in a supracondylar fracture is not progressive.

  • Cubitus varus is a deformity in which the forearm is deviated towards the midline at the elbow.
  • It is also called the gun stock deformity.
  • The most common cause for cubitus varus is the malunion of supracondylar fractures of the humerus in children.
  • Carrying angle is the angle between the long axis of the arm and the long axis of the forearm with the elbow in full extension. In cubitus varus, the carrying angle will decrease.
  • Baumann angle is the humero-capitellar angle, which is measured on an X-ray. In cubitus varus, this angle will increase.
  • The treatment of choice for cubitus varus is the Lateral closing wedge osteotomy.
  • French osteotomy is the most commonly used form of Lateral closing wedge osteotomy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Decreased carrying angle (Option A): True. Cubitus varus is characterised by medial deviation of the forearm, reducing the normal valgus carrying angle.

Increased Baumann angle (Option B): True. An increased Baumann angle on X-ray correlates with varus tilt of the distal humerus.

French osteotomy is used for correction (Option D): True. French-type lateral closing wedge osteotomy is a standard surgical option for correcting the deformity.

questions.text: Which Vascular injury can be seen in the fracture shown in the X-ray?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a displaced supracondylar fracture of the humerus. The brachial artery runs anterior to the distal humerus and is the most commonly injured vascular structure in this type of fracture.

  • Extension-type supracondylar fractures (the most common type) can lead to anterior displacement of the distal fragment.
  • The brachial artery is closely related to the anterior aspect of the distal humerus and is vulnerable to compression, spasm, or transection.
  • Vascular injury is a major early complication, and brachial artery injury is the most feared.
  • Vascular compromise requires urgent recognition and reduction to prevent ischemic complications.

Explanation of Other Options:

Axillary artery (Option B): This lies more proximally, in the axilla, and is not involved in supracondylar fractures.

Radial artery (Option C): This is a distal continuation of the brachial artery and is not commonly affected at the supracondylar level.

Cubital vein (Option D): A superficial vein; not typically injured or clinically significant in supracondylar fractures.

choices.text: Arteriogram of Brachial A and proceed as per findings
Closed reduction of the fracture, slab application and monitoring for reappearance of pulse

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to he casualty with a type III supracondylar fracture of the humerus. His radial and ulnar pulses are not palpable. His hand is pink, and capillary filling is adequate. Next line of management
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In type III supracondylar fracture of the humerus, very often the fracture fragment will press against the Brachial artery and cause it to undergo spasm. This will cause the loss of Radial and Ulnar pulses.

  • However, thankfully, most of the time, the collateral circulation around the elbow becomes active and maintains the perfusion of the limb. Hence, the capillary filling will be normal, and the limb will be pink in colour.
  • This pink limb in the absence of pulses is called the 'Pink pulseless hand'
  • In such a case, the treatment is to reduce the fracture and put a plaster and keep the limb elevated. Then the child is monitored for adequate capillary filling and return of pulses. Most of the time, when the fracture is reduced, the pressure on the Brachial A stops, and the spasm gets relieved, causing the pulses to return. This usually happens within a few hours.
  • If there is no return of pulse even after 6 hours, then surgery needs to be done.

Explanation of Other Options:

Emergency fixation of fracture (Option A): Definitive fixation is not the priority without first reducing the fracture and assessing perfusion response.

Emergency exploration of brachial artery (Option B): Not indicated if hand is well-perfused; exploration is reserved for a white pulseless hand or persistent ischemia.

Arteriogram of brachial artery (Option C): Invasive and unnecessary in an adequately perfused limb; clinical monitoring is sufficient initially.

questions.text: Which of the following fractures do not go in for non-union?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Supracondylar fracture humerus is notorious for malunion and does not undergo nonunion.

  • Nonunion is the failure of healing of a fracture
  • Definition
    • Absence of union even after 9 months of injury and
    • There is no progress radiologically for the last 3 months.
  • Delayed union
    • Absence of union even after 6 months
  • MC bone: distal 1/3rd of tibia

Explanation of Other Options:

Talus fracture (Option A): High risk of non-union due to avascular necrosis and limited blood supply, especially in the talar neck.

Fracture neck of femur (Option C): Commonly undergoes non-union, especially in the elderly, due to intracapsular location and disrupted blood supply.

Scaphoid fracture (Option D): Well known for non-union due to retrograde blood flow and delayed diagnosis, especially waist fractures.

choices.text: Open fracture of the shaft of the humerus

questions.text: Absolute indication of open reduction and internal fixation in a child
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fracture lateral condyle humerus is an absolute indication of open reduction and internal fixation in a child.

  • Complications if untreated or improperly treated include:
    • Non-union
    • Malunion
    • Valgus elbow with delayed ulnar palsy
  • Open reduction and internal fixation is advised if:
    • Displacement > 2 mm
    • Closed manipulation fails
  • The fractures that absolutely need surgical fixation are called 'fractures of necessity'
  • The fractures of necessity are
    • Galeazzi fracture
    • Lateral condyle humerus fracture
    • Fracture neck of femur

Explanation of Other Options:

Monteggia fracture (Option A): Usually treated with closed reduction; ORIF is needed if reduction is unstable.

Open fracture of the shaft of the humerus (Option B): May require debridement and fixation, but is not an absolute indication for ORIF in children.

Fracture shaft of femur (Option C): Treated based on age and displacement; not always an absolute indication for ORIF in children.

questions.text: Which is the earliest sign of compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The earliest sign of compartment syndrome is pain on passive stretch.

Explanation of Other Options:

Tingling sensation (Option A): Indicates paresthesia, a later neurological sign due to nerve compression.

Pain not subsiding with analgesics (Option B): Although a red flag, it is not as specific or early as pain on passive stretch.

Pulselessness (Option C): A late sign indicating arterial compromise, usually after significant ischemic damage.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with increasing pain and tense swelling of the left forearm following a closed injury sustained during a fall. Passive extension of the fingers causes severe pain. Pulses are present, but sensation is diminished over the fingers. The treating physician suspects compartment syndrome. Which of the following is not a common cause of compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gunshot injuries involve open wounds that disrupt the closed fascial compartments, making compartment syndrome less likely.

  • Compartment syndrome is defined as the elevation of pressure in a closed fascial compartment, causing a decrease in perfusion to the limb, leading to irreversible muscle and neurovascular damage.
  • So in compartment syndrome, by definition, there must be a closed fascial compartment for the pressure to build up and rise.

Explanation of Other Options:

Fracture of the proximal tibia (Option A): Common cause due to the enclosed anterior compartment of the leg.

Supracondylar humerus fracture (Option B): Classic pediatric cause of forearm compartment syndrome.

Lisfranc fracture dislocation (Option C): Involves midfoot; can lead to compartment syndrome of the foot.

questions.text: The most common nerve involved in VIC is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most commonly involved nerve in Volkmann ischaemic contracture (VIC) is the median nerve, particularly its anterior interosseous branch.

  • Definition: VIC is a muscle contracture resulting from untreated or inadequately managed compartment syndrome, especially in the forearm.
  • Cause: It results from prolonged ischemia of forearm muscles due to vascular compromise, usually following supracondylar fractures or tight bandaging/plaster.
  • Muscles involved (most to least):
    • Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP)
    • Flexor pollicis longus (FPL)
  • Nerve involvement:
    • Most common: Anterior interosseous nerve (a branch of the median nerve)
    • Then: Median nerve
    • Followed by: Ulnar nerve
  • Clinical deformity:
    • Clawing of fingers with wrist in flexion
    • Inability to extend fingers if the wrist is extended (due to contracture of long flexors)
  • The most common muscles involved are: FDP> FPL
  • The most common nerves involved are: Anterior interosseous Nerve > Median Nerve > and Ulnar Nerve

Explanation of Other Options:

Ulnar nerve (Option B): May be involved but less commonly than the median; often affected in more extensive VIC.

Musculocutaneous nerve (Option C): Not typically involved in VIC as it supplies anterior arm muscles, not the forearm.

Posterior interosseous nerve (Option D): Supplies extensors; not involved in VIC, which is due to ischemia of the flexor compartment.

choices.text: Massage and repeated manipulation are known risk factors
It matures from the periphery to the centre
It is commonly associated with neurological conditions
Inflammation of the muscle is a precursor to ossification

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a gradually increasing, painful swelling over the anterior aspect of the arm following a supracondylar fracture treated with closed reduction 3 weeks ago. On examination, the swelling is firm and mildly tender with restricted elbow extension. X-ray shows a well-demarcated ossified mass in the soft tissues anterior to the humerus. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Myositis ossificans is a misnomer- it is not preceded by muscle inflammation.

  • Definition: Myositis ossificans is a form of heterotopic ossification-bone formation in soft tissue, often post-traumatic.
  • Misnomer: The term "myositis" is incorrect, as there is no muscle inflammation involved.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Repeated manipulations
    • Early massage or stretching
    • Intramuscular hematoma post-trauma
  • Commonly involved muscle: Brachialis (due to proximity to the elbow)
  • Radiology:
    • Peripheral ossification with a radiolucent centre (matures from periphery to centre)
    • Differentiates it from osteosarcoma (which matures centrally)
  • Association: Can occur with head injuries, spinal cord trauma, or burns (neurological conditions).

Explanation of Other Options:

Massage and repeated manipulation are known risk factors (Option A): True; early massage or excessive physiotherapy post-fracture can trigger heterotopic ossification.

It matures from periphery to centre (Option B): True; this radiological appearance is classic and helps differentiate from malignancy.

It is commonly associated with neurological conditions (Option C): True; common in head injury, spinal cord injury, or post-burn.

choices.text: MRI to rule out occult fractures
Manipulate the elbow into supination and flexion
Apply a crepe bandage and repeat the X-ray after 1 week
Apply a plaster cast and repeat X-ray after 1 week

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought in with the history that he had a fight with his older sister, who pulled his hand forcefully to get her favourite toy from him. After this, the boy started crying with pain in his elbow. O/E, the boy is keeping his forearm pronated. The X-ray did not show any fractures. The next step is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario describes a classic case of pulled elbow (subluxation of the radial head), commonly seen in children under 5 years.

  • Mechanism: Longitudinal traction on a pronated forearm (e.g., pulling the child up by the arm).
  • Presentation:
    • The child refuses to move their arm.
    • The arm was held flexed at the elbow with the forearm pronated.
    • No swelling or deformity.
    • The X-ray is normal.
  • Management:
    • No imaging is necessary if the history and exam are classical.
    • Immediate gentle supination and flexion of the forearm often causes a palpable or audible"click"and relieves symptoms.
    • The child resumes normal use of the arm within minutes.

Explanation of Other Options:

MRI to rule out occult fractures (Option A): Not indicated when clinical features are classic and no history of fall/trauma.

Apply crepe bandage and repeat X-ray after 1 week (Option C): Delays effective treatment and causes unnecessary distress.

Apply a plaster cast and repeat X-ray after 1 week (Option D): Overtreatment for a condition that responds to a simple manoeuvre.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after falling directly on his elbow during a bike accident. He complains of pain and swelling around the elbow. On examination, there is localised tenderness and restriction of movement. Lateral X-ray reveals a displaced transverse fracture of the olecranon with intact triceps aponeurosis. What is the most appropriate definitive treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tension band wiring (TBW) is the standard treatment for displaced transverse fractures of the olecranon with intact triceps aponeurosis.

  • The technique uses K-wires and a figure-of-eight stainless steel wire to convert tensile forces generated by the triceps into compressive forces across the fracture.
  • It is particularly suitable for simple transverse fractures, which are the most common olecranon fractures.
  • TBW ensures early mobilisation and good functional outcome.
  • The fractures commonly treated with TBW are
    • Patella
    • Olecranon
    • Medial malleolus

Explanation of Other Options:

Prolonged immobilisation with above-elbow cast (Option B): Used only in elderly/infirm patients with undisplaced stable fractures; not suitable for displaced fractures requiring anatomical alignment.

Arm pouch application (Option C): Inadequate; provides only symptomatic support without promoting healing or alignment.

Intramedullary nailing (Option D): Not used for olecranon fractures; more commonly applied in long bone diaphyseal fractures like the femur or tibia.

questions.text: Identify the fracture shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a fracture of the proximal third of the ulna with anterior dislocation of the radial head, which is diagnostic of a Monteggia fracture-dislocation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Greenstick fracture (Option A): Incomplete fracture typically seen in children; cortex is bent on one side and broken on the other; no dislocation involved.

Galeazzi fracture (Option C): Fracture of the distal third of the radius with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint.

Piedmont fracture (Option D): Another name for Galeazzi fracture; involves radius and distal radioulnar dislocation.

choices.text: Closed reduction of the fracture and cast
Fixation of radius and excision of prominent ulna

questions.text: A 40-year-old man fell from a bike and sustained a fracture of the right forearm. X-ray shows fracture of the lower 1/3rd of the radius with dorsally subluxed ulnar styloid. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A fracture of the lower third of the radius with associated dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint is known as a Galeazzi fracture-dislocation. According to the standard reference, the key to treatment is to restore the length of the fractured radius, which is best achieved by open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF).

  • Galeazzi fracture is a fracture of necessity. This means that the only way of managing it is to do open reduction and internal fixation.
  • The fractures of necessity are
    • Galeazzi fracture
    • Lateral condyle humerus fracture
    • Fracture neck of femur

Explanation of Other Options:

Closed reduction and cast (Option A): Not sufficient for Galeazzi fracture as distal radioulnar joint instability persists without rigid fixation.

Fixation of radius and excision of prominent ulna (Option C): Excision is not indicated; restoring radial length usually stabilises the joint.

External fixation (Option D): Reserved for open fractures or cases with severe soft tissue injury; not first-line.

questions.text: A 62-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with pain and deformity of the wrist after a fall on her outstretched hand. X-ray reveals a dorsally displaced extra-articular fracture of the distal radius. During follow-up, she develops features of median nerve compression and persistent wrist stiffness. Which of the following is not a typical complication of this injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The described injury is a Colles' fracture, a common low-energy dorsally displaced fracture of the distal radius, especially in elderly women due to osteoporosis. Several complications are well-known, mostly involving soft tissue and joint function.

  • Complications of a Colles fracture are
    • Joint stiffness
    • Malunion - causes dinner fork deformity
    • Carpal tunnel syndrome
    • Sudek's osteodystrophy
    • EPL tendon rupture

Explanation of Other Options:

Carpal tunnel syndrome (Option A): A Common complication due to compression of the median nerve.

Sudeck's dystrophy (Option B): A chronic pain syndrome following immobilisation or injury.

Carpal instability (Option D): May result from ligament disruption or malunion.

choices.text: Delayed union due to old age

questions.text: A 65 year old lady had sustained Colle's fracture 2 months back which was treated with POP cast. Plaster was then removed and X ray taken which showed a well united fracture with some osteopenia. But patient developed pain, stiffness and swelling of her hand and wrist. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Persistent pain and stiffness following a seemingly healed distal radius fracture, with features like shiny skin, tenderness, and hypersensitivity, strongly suggest reflex sympathetic dystrophy (RSD)-also termed Complex Regional Pain Syndrome type I.

  • It is also called Sudeck's osteodystrophy.
  • It is a condition where there is diffuse pain and stiffness of a limb after trauma/immobilisation.
  • Cause
    • Unknown
    • Thought to be due to autonomic dysfunction
  • Symptoms
    • Pain even after fracture healing
    • Pain out of proportion to signs
    • Stiffness
  • Signs
    • Diffuse edema
    • Shiny skin
    • Hyperalgesia
    • Stiffness
  • Treatment
    • Physiotherapy
      • Exercises
      • Wax bath
      • TENS
    • Gabapentin
    • Amitriptyline

Explanation of Other Options:

Refracture (Option A): Unlikely if X-ray shows complete union and no trauma reoccurred.

Delayed union due to old age (Option B): Pain due to delayed union is usually not associated with shiny skin or autonomic features.

Osteoporotic pain (Option C): Osteoporosis is common in this age group, but does not cause such localised, intense symptoms or skin changes.

choices.text: APL pull is insignificant in the Rolando fracture
Extensive comminution is the hallmark of Bennett fracture

questions.text: The false statement is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bennett's fracture is an intra-articular fracture dislocation at the base of the first metacarpal. It is typically not comminuted, but instead involves a single oblique fracture with displacement caused by the strong pull of the abductor pollicis longus (APL) tendon. In contrast, Rolando's fracture is an intra-articular fracture with comminution, usually presenting with a T- or Y-shaped configuration.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rolando fracture is intra-articular (Option A): It involves a comminuted intra-articular base fracture.

Bennett fracture is always displaced (Option B): Due to the pull of the APL tendon.

APL pull is significant in Bennett fracture (Option C): It causes radial displacement of the shaft.

choices.text: Waist fractures are the commonest in children
AVN is most common in the Distal pole
Blood supply is from distal to proximal

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with pain in the wrist following a fall on his outstretched hand. Examination reveals tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox. Initial X-rays are inconclusive. A repeat X-ray after 10 days reveals a fracture at the waist of the scaphoid. The orthopaedic surgeon warns the patient about the risk of complications due to the vascular anatomy of the scaphoid. Which of the following statements about scaphoid fractures is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The characteristic retrograde blood supply of the scaphoid, which enters from the distal pole and travels proximally, makes the proximal pole vulnerable to avascular necrosis.

  • Distal pole scaphoid fractures are the most common in children.
  • The most common complication of scaphoid fracture is Nonunion > AVN
  • Both AVN and nonunion are most common in proximal pole fractures.
  • This is because of the weird blood supply of the scaphoid, which enters via the distal pole and goes proximally.

Explanation of Other Options:

Waist fractures are the commonest in children (Option A): Incorrect. Tubercle fractures are more frequent in children.

AVN is the most common complication (Option B): Incorrect. Non-union or delayed union is more frequent.

AVN is most common in the distal pole (Option C): Incorrect. The proximal pole is more prone to AVN due to poor blood supply.

questions.text: Spilled teacup sign is seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Spilled teacup sign refers to the volar tilting of the lunate bone seen in lunate dislocation on a lateral wrist X-ray, where the lunate is displaced anteriorly and loses articulation with both the radius and capitate.

Spilled teacup sign

Explanation of Other Options:

Scapholunate dislocation (Option A): Characterised by a widened scapholunate space (Terry Thomas sign), not a spilled teacup appearance.

Scaphoid fracture (Option B): Fracture through the scaphoid bone, commonly waist; no characteristic spilled teacup sign.

Perilunate dislocation (Option D): Lunate remains aligned with radius; capitate is displaced dorsally-teacup remains upright.

questions.text: A 23-year-old lady has recently delivered a baby and is now complaining of pain in her left wrist for 1 month. O/E, there is tenderness over the radial styloid, and the Finkelstein test is positive. Which structures are affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pain over the radial styloid with a positive Finkelstein's test is characteristic of De Quervain's tenosynovitis, which involves the first dorsal compartment tendons - abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB).

  • Symptoms - Pain over the wrist and base of the thumb
  • Signs - Tenderness over radial styloid and Finkelstein test +ve
  • Finkelstein test
    • The patient is asked to clench the fist with the thumb inside the palm.
    • Then the wrist is ulnar deviated, causing pain
  • Treatment
    • Thumb spica splint
    • Steroid injection
    • Surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment

Explanation of Other Options:

EPL and APB (Option B): Not anatomically grouped together; EPL is in the 3rd compartment, APB is intrinsic.

Adductor Pollicis (Option C): Intrinsic hand muscle; not related to tenosynovitis.

Scaphoid (Option D): Bone, not a tendon; fracture causes anatomical snuffbox tenderness, not positive Finkelstein’s test.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic and alcoholic patient presented with flexion deformity of his ring finger. There is a thick cord-like structure palpable on the palmar aspect of the ring finger. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis is Dupuytren's contracture, which presents as a flexion deformity of the fingers (especially the ring and little fingers) due to fibrous contracture of the palmar fascia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Trigger finger (Option A): Presents with catching or locking of a finger due to thickening of the flexor tendon sheath, not a fixed contracture.

Claw hand deformity (Option C): Involves hyperextension at the MCP and flexion at IP joints, seen in ulnar nerve palsy, not palmar fascia pathology.

Swan neck deformity (Option D): Seen in RA or trauma; PIP hyperextension with DIP flexion.

questions.text: In the trigger finger, the tendon sheath constriction is at the level of which pulley?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The constriction in trigger finger typically occurs at the A1 pulley, which lies just proximal to the MCP joint. Thickening of the flexor tendon or its sheath causes the tendon to catch when it passes under this pulley, leading to painful snapping or locking of the finger.

  • Most commonly affected finger: Ring finger
  • Most commonly affected tendon: Flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) or profundus (FDP)

  • Clinical signs include:
    • Pain and clicking during finger movement
    • Locking of the finger in flexion
    • A palpable nodule over the MCP joint
  • Treatment:
    • Conservative: Corticosteroid injection at the level of A1 pulley
    • Surgical: Release of A1 pulley

Explanation of Other Options:

A2 (Option B): Located on the proximal phalanx; crucial for maintaining tendon position, not commonly involved in trigger finger.

A3 (Option C): Located at the level of the PIP joint; rarely involved in triggering symptoms.

A4 (Option D): Over middle phalanx; constriction here is not typical for trigger finger pathology.

choices.text: Injury to the ulnar digital nerve of the thumb
Osteoarthritis of the IP joint of the thumb

questions.text: What is the pathology in Bowler's thumb?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bowler's thumb is a compressive neuropathy caused by repetitive pressure on the ulnar digital nerve of the thumb. It occurs most commonly in bowlers due to prolonged contact and friction with the bowling ball's thumbhole.

  • Pathology: Perineural fibrosis of the ulnar digital nerve
  • Clinical features:
    • Pain, numbness, or tingling in the thumb
    • Palpable tender mass
    • Decreased grip due to discomfort
  • Treatment:
    • Rest and avoidance of provoking activity
    • Surgical options include neurolysis or digital nerve transposition in persistent cases

Explanation of Other Options:

Callus in the index finger (Option B): Not characteristic of bowler's thumb; may be seen with gripping instruments but not pathognomonic.

Tendon rupture due to overuse (Option C): Seen in sports with eccentric loading (e.g., weightlifting), not typical of bowler's thumb.

Osteoarthritis of the IP joint of the thumb (Option D): Presents with joint pain and stiffness, unrelated to perineural fibrosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a non-tender, cystic swelling in the dorsum of the wrist as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a well-defined cystic swelling on the dorsum of the wrist, which is typical of a ganglion cyst, the most common swelling around the wrist and hand.

  • Pathology:
    • Originates from the leakage of synovial fluid from a joint or tendon sheath.
    • Commonly arises from the scapholunate ligament.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Often affects young adults.
    • Painless or slightly aching cystic lump.
    • Does not move with the tendon motion.
    • Frequently occurs on the dorsum of the wrist (most common site).
  • Treatment:
    • Observation if asymptomatic.
    • Aspiration with/without steroid injection.
    • Surgical excision is indicated if symptomatic, recurrent, or causing nerve compression.

Explanation of Other Options:

Wrist synovitis (Option A): Presents with pain and diffuse swelling, often in inflammatory arthritis-not a localised cystic swelling.

GCT of distal radius (Option B): Typically a bony lesion, not a superficial cystic lump.

Meniscal cyst (Option D): Occurs around the knee joint, not the wrist.

questions.text: Hourglass abscess is seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Compound palmar ganglion refers to chronic inflammation distending the common flexor sheath both above and below the flexor retinaculum, producing a dumbbell/hourglass-shaped swelling across the carpal tunnel.

  • It is usually seen in TB.
  • Can cause Carpal Tunnel Syndrome

Clinical Features:

  • Pain is unusual, but paresthesia due to median nerve compression may occur.
  • The swelling is hourglass-shaped, bulging above and below the flexor retinaculum.
  • The swelling is not warm or tender.
  • Cross-fluctuation is present - fluid may be pushed from one part to the other.

Treatment:

  • If tuberculous, treat with anti-tubercular drugs.
  • Streptomycin may be instilled locally.
  • Wrist rested in a splint.
  • Surgery is reserved for cases causing nerve compression or rupture risk.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ganglion cyst (Option A): Cystic lesion due to synovial fluid leakage, not hourglass-shaped.

Wrist synovitis (Option C): Inflammatory swelling of the tendon sheaths, not dumbbell-shaped.

Furuncles (Option D): Superficial abscess of hair follicles, localised and not transcompartmental.
